pullRequest.body:
* Add `import Mathlib.Tactic.GCongr.Core`
  to `Algebra/Order/Ring/Lemmas`.
* Move most `@[gcongr]` tags next to the lemmas.

See [Zulip thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Mathlib.2FTactic.2FGCongr)

---
- [x] Is there a better home for setting up `positivity`
  as a `gcongr` discharger?
- [x] What should we do with `Nat` division lemmas?

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
> > Is there a better home for setting up positivity as a gcongr discharger?
> 
> I think the current setup is fine enough.

It's a footgun: `gcongr` kind of works without importing `Mathlib.Tactic.GCongr` but doesn't use `positivity`. To reduce damage, we can `import` this file very early as soon as both `Positivity.Core` and `GCongr.Core` are imported. OTOH, we already have a similar footgun with `Positivity.Core` vs `Positivity`, so maybe the right way to solve the issue is to add documentation to `gcongr` and `positivity` ("if the tactic fails, first make sure that your file imports ...").

> so maybe the right way to solve the issue is to add documentation to `gcongr` and `positivity` ("if the tactic fails, first make sure that your file imports ...").

Just solve the issue as you see fit, then.
Do you still think there is a problem with the `positivity` import or is this ready?
It's ready for review (there is an `awaiting-review` label to signal this).

LGTM, modulo: did this get resolved?

> I'm good with importing positivity as early as possible. Should I ask on Zulip for other opinions?

Yes, negatively. `positivity` can't be imported earlier than `Field` because of the `norm_num` support at the core of the tactic. So #10140 only moves the extensions that depend on `Field` anyway. Further, `Tactic.Positivity.Basic` imports extra cast material that is unimportable in most of the algebraic order hierarchy, so we must restrict to importing only `Tactic.Positivity.Core` there.
#10140 has been merged. You can adapt this PR to it.
Merged `master`, fixed compile.
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7869587215/job/21468990392)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7869587215/job/21468989621)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7869587215/job/21468990137)
maintainer merge

LGTM, thanks!

bors r+

> Is there a better home for setting up positivity as a gcongr discharger?

I think the current setup is fine enough.

This basically looks fine to me. A few small issues:

1. Not for this PR, but the fact that `Algebra.Order.Ring.Defs` imports the `.Lemmas` file is weird. I opened a [Zulip thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Lemmas.20vs.E2.80.8C.20Defs/near/416948726).
2. what are the `tt - ff` comments in the `GCongr` file, which are being deleted in this PR. Are we losing information of some sort?
3. It would be nice to have documented somewhere an example of a "bad" `gcongr` lemmma (i.e., one that a user might at first glance think would be a good lemma, but actually isn't for some reason). I don't see this currently covered.
maintainer merge

LGTM, thanks!

bors r+

Yes, we do need it. I removed `@[gcongr]` from this lemma and L777 of `Analysis.Normed.Field.Basic` errored:
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/b50557ce70bf397971b2ba89d7c532c36a163e5f/Mathlib/Analysis/Normed/Field/Basic.lean#L771-L777
You never doubted that both `div_lt_div` and `div_lt_div_of_lt_left` should be gcongr lemmas, so if you never doubted `div_le_div`, how can `div_le_div_of_le_left` _not_ be a gcongr lemma without breaking something else in mathlib?

```suggestion
@[gcongr]
```

The three remaining gcongr lemmas in `Tactic.GCongr` can be untagged **entirely** and mathlib still builds perfectly, see https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/41f1b572c9ea37556e2252d9076cb51f1f5ee381
But they should be tagged if we want `gcongr` to work with `Nat` division.

My experiment showed that `gcongr` is not used to handle `Nat` division anywhere in the current library. I therefore suggest that tests be added where `gcongr` exercises `Nat` division:
```lean
-- â„•-division tests
example (a b c : â„•) (hâ‚ : c â‰¤ b) (hâ‚‚ : 0 < c) : a / b â‰¤ a / c := by gcongr

example (a b c : â„•) (h : a â‰¤ b) : a / c â‰¤ b / c := by gcongr

example (a b c d : â„•) (h1 : a â‰¤ b) (h2 : c â‰¤ d) (h0 : 0 < c) :
  (a + 1) / (d + 2) â‰¤ (b + 1) / (c + 2) := by gcongr
```
and that the `gcongr` tags be shifted, alongside `Nat.div_le_div`, into `Data.Nat.Basic`. We should also find places where `gcongr` can shorten a proof involving a `Nat.div_le_div*` lemma.
Is there a reason not to simply import `Mathlib.Tactic.GCongr` here? That is, do we really not want to import `Mathlib.Tactic.Positivity`(`.Core`) here?
I'm good with importing positivity as early as possible. Should I ask on Zulip for other opinions?
I see that @semorrison recently removed some imports of `positivity`. Scott, what do you think about this?
@j-loreaux, it would cause an import cycle!
So, should I merge `master`, wait for CI and merge?
Yes, go ahead and do that.

> Yes, go ahead and do that.

I'm waiting for an official `bors d+` from another maintainer.
There's #10140 in the mix now. Would you like to adapt your PR to that? (cc @YaelDillies)
Does the same concern not apply to `gcongr`?
It doesn't apply; `gcongr` wants left/right lemmas even if the "both arguments" lemma implies both of them.

```suggestion
@[gcongr] alias âŸ¨_, GCongr.zpow_lt_of_ltâŸ© := zpow_lt_iff_lt
```

It doesn't make sense to me to put this in the `GCongr` namespace for two reasons:
1. We don't have much else there, especially not many lemmas.
2. These declarations existed already and were not in that namespace, so we would have to add an alias and a deprecation, but that seems silly.
I like the idea of moving auxiliary lemmas that exist only because `gcongr` can't handle `Monotone`/`StrictMono`/`Iff` lemmas to the `GCongr` namespace.

```suggestion
theorem GCongr.cast_le_cast {a b : â„•} (h : a â‰¤ b) : (a : Î±) â‰¤ b := mono_cast h
```
Same comment as above.

This is a lemma internal to `GCongr`. If we don't namespace it, people, will be confused between `Nat.cast_le`, `Nat.cast_le_cast` and `Nat.cast_mono`. Further, the argument that we don't have much in the `GCongr` namespace doesn't hold since `gcongr` is so new.
This lemma was (not-namespaced) in `Tactic/GCongr`. We can move it to the `GCongr` namespace and deprecate the old lemma in favor of `Nat.mono_cast`.

I would consider the original lack of namespacing as an accident. I think we should not even deprecate but delete, since `Nat.cast_le` should really be called `Nat.cast_le_cast` and the current `Nat.cast_le_cast` hasn't been around for long.
I deprecated old lemmas.

to follow ISO recommendations
```suggestion
@[deprecated] -- Since 2024-02-10
```
Probably you meant this to go on the `@[deprecated]` above?

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(Tactic/GCongr): move `@[gcongr]` tags around

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: counting elements in an interval with given residue
